title: Former umpire Springstead passes away
subtitle: Former umpire Springstead passes away
body: A longtime umpire and umpire supervisor, whose work in and with the Major Leagues spanned more than 40 years, has passed away, Major League Baseball announced on Wednesday.  Marty Springstead, a native of Nyack, N.Y., was found dead at his Florida home on Tuesday night. He was 74.  "For a quarter-century, Marty mentored a new generation of our umpires, not only in the Major Leagues but around the world," Commissioner Bud Selig said. "Marty was an avid teacher, a great storyteller and a friend to countless people around our game. Like so many of my colleagues, I always appreciated his wonderful sense of humor and the pride he had for his profession. On behalf of Major League Baseball and Marty's friends and admirers throughout the game, I extend my deepest condolences to his wife, Linda; his son, Bradley, and Bradley's mother Marlene; and his stepson, Robert." Springstead was an American League umpire from 1966-85 and worked the World Series in 1973, 1978 and 1983. He became the AL's executive director of umpires from 1986-2000, then worked as an umpire supervisor for MLB after staffs from the leagues merged. That job ran through 2010.   Springstead lectured around the world, teaching umpiring in clinics in Canada, Germany, Japan, the Netherlands and Spain. Evan Drellich is a reporter for MLB.com. Follow him on Twitter @EvanDrellich. This story was not subject to the approval of Major League Baseball or its clubs.
author: Evan Drellich
